stem: The nurse is performing a dressing change for a central venous catheter (CVC). Place the actions in the correct order to minimize the risk of infection and air embolism.

options.text: Apply a sterile transparent semi-permeable dressing.
Perform hand hygiene and don clean gloves and a mask.
Remove the old dressing and discard clean gloves.
Perform hand hygiene and don sterile gloves.
Cleanse the site with Chlorhexidine (scrubbing back and forth) and let dry.

pedagogy.nclexCategory: Safety and Infection Prevention and Control

rationale.correct: CVC management requires strict asepsis to prevent CLABSI. (1) Masks (for nurse and client) prevent respiratory droplet contamination. (2) Removal is a 'clean' task. (3) Transition to 'sterile' is mandatory for site prep. (4) Chlorhexidine requires mechanical friction and full drying to be effective. (5) Transparent dressings allow for continuous monitoring of the site.
rationale.incorrect: Using an circular 'inner-to-outer' cleaning motion is outdated for chlorhexidine; the recommended method is a 'back-and-forth' scrub.
clinicalPearls: Always have the client turn their head away from the insertion site during the dressing change to further reduce droplet contamination.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that you only need the client to hold their breath (Valsalva) when *removing* the entire CVC, not during a dressing change.

reviewUnits.heading: Prevention of Central Line-Associated Bloodstream Infections (CLABSI)
reviewUnits.body: Nurses must perform daily audits of line necessity and maintain strict hand hygiene before any line manipulation.
